Exaggerate: The claim of a COVID-19 patient being nearly buried alive is exaggerated as the video shows a person fainting during a burial ceremony, not being buried alive.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support as there is no evidence or confirmation that the person in the video was actually a COVID-19 patient.
Exist alternative explanation: The alternative explanation provided by Stanley Mutai and Gilbert Korir, stating that the person fainted due to discomfort from wearing the PPE, suggests an alternative explanation to the claim of the patient being nearly buried alive.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that Kenya's ministry of health guidelines require Covid-19 infected corpses to be placed in tamper-proof body bags, which was not the case in the video.
Falters at times: The claim falters by presenting a misleading narrative that the patient was nearly buried alive, while the expert's verdict clarifies that it was a case of fainting during a burial ceremony.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the video depicts a COVID-19 patient being nearly buried alive without providing sufficient evidence or confirmation of the person's COVID-19 status.
